title: 107_hr4734
content:
The Act is titled the "Alaska Federal Lands Management Demonstration Project Act." The Alaska National Interest Lands Conservation Act established new units in the National Park System and National Wildlife Refuge System in Alaska to protect habitat, wildlife, and cultural sites. Rural Alaskan communities near these units have unique cultural ties to the conservation efforts. The Alaska National Interest Lands Conservation Act established programs to give preference to Alaska Native lands for conservation system unit facilities, Alaska Native corporations for visitor services, and local residents for employment. The Act aims to promote innovative management strategies, expand Alaska Native contracting opportunities, increase local employment, and further the unique purposes of conservation system units. The Alaska National Interest Lands Conservation Act aims to further the unique purposes of conservation system units related to subsistence practices, Alaska Native culture, and the conservation of fish and wildlife habitat and populations. The Alaska Federal Lands Management Demonstration Project is outlined in SEC. 3. The Alaska Federal Lands Management Demonstration Project allows 12 Indian tribes or tribal organizations in Alaska to contract for construction, maintenance, research, and monitoring on conservation units. Eligible tribes must request participation through official action. The Indian tribe or tribal organization must show financial stability, no unresolved audit exceptions for 3 years, and significant reliance on the conservation unit to request programs under contract. If multiple tribes meet the criteria, the Secretary will prioritize based on selection criteria. The Secretary will use priority selection criteria from the Alaska Region of the Bureau of Indian Affairs for contracting under the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act. If multiple eligible tribes have overlapping requests, they must agree on who can contract or submit a joint request. Selected tribes must complete a planning phase before negotiations. Prior to negotiating and entering into a conservation system unit management contract, a planning phase must be completed to the satisfaction of the Secretary, Indian tribe, or tribal organization. This phase includes legal and budgetary research, as well as internal tribal planning and organizational preparation. Upon request, the Secretary will negotiate and enter into a contract with the Indian tribe or tribal organization for them to plan, conduct, and administer programs, services, functions, and activities as requested. (g) Contract Administration.--
Upon completion of the planning phase required by subsection (e), the Secretary must initiate and conclude negotiations with the participating Indian tribe or tribal organization within 90 days, unless an alternative schedule is agreed upon. The Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act's declination and appeals provisions apply to contracts and agreements requested and negotiated under this Act. Contracts entered into under this Act may include benefits, terms, and conditions from agreements under the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act. Provisions from the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act will have the same force and effect in this Act. Parties can also agree on additional terms as long as they are not contrary to law. Contracts under this Act require a single-agency audit report as per title 31, US Code. Career Federal employees during a transfer to an Indian tribe will not lose their jobs and can be supervised by the tribe. Transferred employees have priority for positions within their agency. Under the Act, contracts with Indian tribes ensure funding not less than what the Secretary would have provided. Advance payments are made in annual or semiannual installments. Tribes must complete planning within a year of selection for the project. Contracts with Indian tribes under the Act ensure funding not less than what the Secretary would have provided, with advance payments made in installments. Tribes must complete planning within a year of project selection. Participating tribes may implement requested contracts at the start of the next fiscal year, with the option for an alternate schedule. Contracts can last for 5 consecutive fiscal years. The Secretary must report to Congress on the costs and benefits of the project, identifying barriers and providing recommendations for improvement. The reports shall contain recommendations for improving, continuing, and expanding the demonstration project, authored jointly with all participating Indian tribes and tribal organizations. Contracts authorized under this Act shall not include revenue-producing visitor services without agreement from Alaska Native corporations. Such contracts shall not grant authority to administer permits, licenses, or contracts related to. The Denali National Park is exempt from the provisions of the Act. The Act does not affect Alaska's authority for managing fish and wildlife. Planning grants of $100,000 are available for Indian tribes to plan for contracting programs and services. An Indian tribe or tribal organization may choose to meet the planning phase requirement without applying for a grant under this subsection. No tribe may receive more than 1 grant under this subsection. $600,000 is authorized for each of the 2 fiscal years following the Act's enactment for planning grants. SEC. 4. KOYUKUK AND KANUTI NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGES DEMONSTRATION PROJECT. The Secretary will establish a demonstration project with the Koyukuk River Basin Moose Co-Management Team, Inc. to provide programs and services of the Koyukuk and Kanuti National Wildlife Refuges. Contracts will ensure that employees from the United States Fish and Wildlife Service are assigned to the contractor while retaining their federal benefits and status. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. This section defines key terms such as "conservation system unit," "Indian tribe," "Secretary," and "tribal organization" for the purposes of the Act.
